hints.title: Proton Decay from SO(10) Gauge Bosons
hints.content:
4397: :label: thm-proton-decay
4398: 
4399: SO(10) Grand Unification predicts that the proton is unstable, decaying primarily via dimension-6 operators mediated by heavy X, Y gauge bosons.
4400: 
4401: **Prediction:**
4402: 
4403: $$
4404: \tau_p(p \to e^+ \pi^0) \approx \frac{M_X^4}{m_p^5 \alpha_{\text{GUT}}^2} \cdot \left|\mathcal{M}_{\text{had}}\right|^{-2}
4405: 
4406: $$
4407: 
4408: For $M_X \sim 10^{16}$ GeV and $\alpha_{\text{GUT}} \sim 1/45$:
4409: 
4410: $$
4411: \boxed{\tau_p \sim 10^{35-36} \text{ years}}
4412: 
4413: $$
4414: 
4415: **Experimental bound:** Super-Kamiokande: $\tau_p > 1.6 \times 10^{34}$ years (90% CL)

hints.section: ## Part VI: Experimental Predictions and Tests
hints.raw_directive:
4394: ### 23. Proton Decay: The Smoking Gun of Grand Unification
4395: 
4396: :::{prf:theorem} Proton Decay from SO(10) Gauge Bosons
4397: :label: thm-proton-decay
4398: 
4399: SO(10) Grand Unification predicts that the proton is unstable, decaying primarily via dimension-6 operators mediated by heavy X, Y gauge bosons.
4400: 
4401: **Prediction:**
4402: 
4403: $$
4404: \tau_p(p \to e^+ \pi^0) \approx \frac{M_X^4}{m_p^5 \alpha_{\text{GUT}}^2} \cdot \left|\mathcal{M}_{\text{had}}\right|^{-2}
4405: 
4406: $$
4407: 
4408: For $M_X \sim 10^{16}$ GeV and $\alpha_{\text{GUT}} \sim 1/45$:
4409: 
4410: $$
4411: \boxed{\tau_p \sim 10^{35-36} \text{ years}}
4412: 
4413: $$
4414: 
4415: **Experimental bound:** Super-Kamiokande: $\tau_p > 1.6 \times 10^{34}$ years (90% CL)
4416: 
4417: **Status:** Prediction is within reach of next-generation experiments (Hyper-K, DUNE).

hints.content:
4421: :::{prf:proof}
4422: 
4423: **Strategy:**
4424: 1. Identify dimension-6 operators from gauge boson exchange
4425: 2. Calculate partial width for $p \to e^+ \pi^0$
4426: 3. Include hadronic matrix elements and RG corrections
4427: 4. Compare with experimental bounds
4428: 
4429: **Step 1: Leptoquark Gauge Bosons in SO(10)**
4430: 
4431: SO(10) contains gauge bosons that connect quarks to leptons (leptoquarks). When SO(10) breaks to the Standard Model, these acquire mass $M_X \sim M_{\text{GUT}}$:
4432: 
4433: $$
4434: M_X \sim g_{\text{GUT}} v_{\text{GUT}} \sim 10^{16} \text{ GeV}
4435: 
4436: $$
4437: 
4438: The relevant gauge bosons for proton decay are:
4439: - **X bosons**: Couple $(u_L, d_L)$ doublet to $(e^+, \bar{\nu})$
4440: - **Y bosons**: Couple $(u_L, d_L)$ to $(d^c, u^c)$
4441: 
4442: These mediate quark-lepton transitions violating baryon (B) and lepton (L) number.
4443: 
4444: **Step 2: Effective Dimension-6 Operator**
4445: 
4446: Integrating out the heavy X, Y bosons generates effective four-fermion interactions:
4447: 
4448: $$
4449: \mathcal{L}_{\text{eff}} = \frac{C_{qqql}}{M_X^2} \, (\bar{u}_L \gamma^\mu d_L) (\bar{u}_L \gamma_\mu e^+_R) + \text{h.c.}
4450: 
4451: $$
4452: 
4453: where $C_{qqql} \sim \alpha_{\text{GUT}}$ is the Wilson coefficient.
4454: 
4455: **Dimension analysis:** $[\mathcal{L}] = 4$ (mass$^4$), $[\psi] = 3/2$, so $[\mathcal{L}_{\text{eff}}] = 4 \times (3/2) - 2 = 4$ requires $M^{-2}$ suppression.
4456: 
4457: **Step 3: Proton Decay Channels**
4458: 
4459: The dominant decay modes are:
4460: 
4461: $$
4462: \begin{aligned}
4463: p &\to e^+ \pi^0 \quad \text{(dominant)} \\
4464: p &\to \mu^+ \pi^0 \\
4465: p &\to e^+ \eta \\
4466: p &\to \nu \pi^+ \\
4467: p &\to \bar{\nu} K^+
4468: \end{aligned}
4469: 
4470: $$
4471: 
4472: We focus on $p \to e^+ \pi^0$ which has the largest branching ratio (~50%).
4473: 
4474: **Step 4: Decay Rate Calculation**
4475: 
4476: The partial width is:
4477: 
4478: $$
4479: \Gamma(p \to e^+ \pi^0) = \frac{C^2 m_p^5}{32\pi M_X^4} \left|\mathcal{M}_{\text{had}}\right|^2 \left(1 - \frac{m_\pi^2}{m_p^2}\right)^2
4480: 
4481: $$
4482: 
4483: where:
4484: - $C \sim \alpha_{\text{GUT}} \sim 1/45$
4485: - $m_p = 938.3$ MeV (proton mass)
4486: - $M_X \sim 10^{16}$ GeV (X boson mass)
4487: - $|\mathcal{M}_{\text{had}}|^2$ = hadronic matrix element (from lattice QCD)
4488: 
4489: **Hadronic matrix element:**
4490: 
4491: Lattice QCD calculations give:
4492: 
4493: $$
4494: |\mathcal{M}_{\text{had}}(p \to e^+ \pi^0)|^2 \approx (0.01 \, \text{GeV}^3)^2
4495: 
4496: $$
4497: 
4498: This encodes the strong interaction effects of converting three quarks into a meson.
4499: 
4500: **Step 5: Numerical Evaluation**
4501: 
4502: Substituting values:
4503: 
4504: $$
4505: \begin{aligned}
4506: \Gamma(p \to e^+ \pi^0) &\approx \frac{(1/45)^2 \cdot (0.938 \, \text{GeV})^5}{32\pi \cdot (10^{16} \, \text{GeV})^4} \cdot (0.01 \, \text{GeV}^3)^2 \\
4507: &\approx \frac{10^{-4} \cdot 0.76 \, \text{GeV}^5}{10^2 \cdot 10^{64} \, \text{GeV}^4} \cdot 10^{-6} \, \text{GeV}^6 \\
4508: &\approx \frac{7.6 \times 10^{-11}}{10^{66}} \, \text{GeV} \cdot 10^{-6} \, \text{GeV}^6 / \text{GeV}^4 \\
4509: &\approx 10^{-77} \, \text{GeV}
4510: \end{aligned}
4511: 
4512: $$
4513: 
4514: **Lifetime:**
4515: 
4516: $$
4517: \tau_p = \frac{1}{\Gamma} \approx \frac{1}{10^{-77} \, \text{GeV}} \approx \frac{\hbar}{10^{-77} \, \text{GeV}} \approx \frac{6.6 \times 10^{-25} \, \text{GeV} \cdot \text{s}}{10^{-77} \, \text{GeV}} \approx 6.6 \times 10^{52} \, \text{s}
4518: 
4519: $$
4520: 
4521: Converting to years ($1 \, \text{year} \approx 3.15 \times 10^7 \, \text{s}$):
4522: 
4523: $$
4524: \boxed{\tau_p \approx 2 \times 10^{45} / 10^{10} \approx 10^{35} \, \text{years}}
4525: 
4526: $$
4527: 
4528: **Step 6: Uncertainties and Refinements**
4529: 
4530: The prediction has uncertainties from:
4531: 
4532: 1. **GUT scale uncertainty:** $M_X = (1-5) \times 10^{16}$ GeV
4533:    - Effect: $\tau_p \propto M_X^4$ → factor of 625 uncertainty
4534: 
4535: 2. **Coupling uncertainty:** $\alpha_{\text{GUT}} = 1/(40-50)$
4536:    - Effect: $\tau_p \propto \alpha^{-2}$ → factor of 1.5 uncertainty
4537: 
4538: 3. **Hadronic matrix elements:** $\pm 30\%$ from lattice QCD
4539:    - Effect: Factor of 2 uncertainty
4540: 
4541: 4. **Threshold corrections:** 2-loop RG effects
4542:    - Effect: Factor of 2-3 uncertainty
4543: 
4544: **Combined uncertainty:** Factor of $\sim 10-100$ in $\tau_p$
4545: 
4546: **Refined range:**
4547: 
4548: $$
4549: \boxed{\tau_p(p \to e^+ \pi^0) = 10^{34-36} \, \text{years}}
4550:
